intro: Pinus pumilio var. variabilis, commonly known as the variable dwarf pine, is a variant of the whitebark pine native to the high-altitude regions of South America. This plant is characterized by its small, conical shape and needle-like leaves, which are typically shorter and more densely packed than those of the standard whitebark pine. It produces small, red-brown cones that release seeds in the fall, contributing to its reproductive cycle. The plant is adapted to harsh, cold environments, with a slow growth rate and a long lifespan. Its botanical features make it an important species in alpine ecosystems, providing habitat and food for various wildlife.
